commander.name: Major-General Sir Michael O'Moore Creagh
commander.previous_service: Succeeded Major-General Percy Hobart as GOC 7th Armoured Division
commander.notes: Led the division during Operation Compass (Dec 1940 - Feb 1941)

tanks.notes: Tank strength heavily depleted after Operation Compass; many units withdrawn for maintenance

Ordnance QF 18-pounder.role: Older field gun still in service

fighters.notes: Air support provided by RAF Western Desert Air Force, not organic to division

supply_status.notes: Supply situation improved after Bardia and Tobruk captures; substantial Italian stocks seized
logistics_challenges: Water most critical commodity in desert
Many vehicles running on captured Italian fuel

subordinate_units.notes: 8th Hussars (withdrawn late January), 1st RTR, 2nd RTR (Beda Fomm)
subordinate_units.status: Units rotating to Cairo for maintenance

subordinate_units.notes: Formed 22 Jan 1940 to provide infantry and artillery support to armoured brigades

composition: 11th Hussars (Prince Albert's Own) - Divisional Reconnaissance Regiment
subordinate_units.notes: 11th Hussars conducted famous long-range reconnaissance missions during Operation Compass

subordinate_units.equipment: 23 Matilda Mk I, 16 Matilda Mk II
subordinate_units.status: Attached for Operation Compass - not organic to division
subordinate_units.notes: Provided infantry tank support at Bardia (3 Jan) and Tobruk; 'worth a whole battalion' per Maj-Gen Mackay

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armoured division for deep exploitation and pursuit operations in desert terrain
special_capabilities: Independent mobile operations with minimal supply line dependence
Combined arms coordination between armour, motorized infantry, and mobile artillery
tactical_innovations: Use of jock columns - mixed tank, infantry, and artillery mobile battle groups
Long-range reconnaissance screen using armoured cars (11th Hussars)
Desert navigation using sun compass and astronomical navigation
Wide flanking movements through 'impassable' desert terrain
known_issues: Chronic mechanical unreliability of cruiser tanks in desert conditions
Excessive track mileage causing widespread breakdowns
Shortage of tank spare parts and recovery vehicles
Light tanks (Mk VI) too lightly armed and armoured for combat
2-pounder gun lacks HE round for anti-infantry work
Supply lines stretched thin during rapid advances
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive modifications for desert operations including sand filters, extra water and fuel stowage, sun compasses, and desert camouflage schemes. Units developed expertise in desert navigation and logistics.

combat_readiness.morale: High - boosted by recent victories at Sidi Barrani, Bardia, and impending Tobruk assault
combat_readiness.experience_level: Veteran - experienced in desert warfare and mobile operations
combat_readiness.maintenance_status: Poor - many units withdrawn for maintenance after Operation Compass
combat_readiness.tank_availability: Only 75% operational due to mechanical wear
combat_readiness.notes: Division desperately needs maintenance halt after extended combat operations Dec 1940 - Jan 1941

special_rules: Desert Rats: +1 to desert terrain movement and navigation
Mechanical Attrition: -1 operational tank per game day due to breakdowns
Extended Supply Lines: Supply range limited to 150km from base
Reconnaissance Excellence: 11th Hussars provide superior scouting
Italian Tank Superiority: British 2-pdr effective vs M13/40
historical_engagements: Beda Fomm (5-7 Feb 1941) - destroyed Italian 10th Army
victory_conditions: Destroy or capture enemy armoured forces
Maintain operational tempo despite mechanical breakdowns

commonwealth_forces.notes: Per user instructions: British includes ALL Commonwealth forces
commonwealth_forces.south_african_contribution: Marmon-Herrington armoured cars crewed by South African personnel; some South African engineer and support units attached
commonwealth_forces.australian_cooperation: 7th Armoured Division provided armoured support to 6th Australian Division at Bardia and coordinated operations throughout Operation Compass
commonwealth_forces.new_zealand_contribution: Limited - primarily in other formations during this period
commonwealth_forces.indian_contribution: 7th Armoured coordinated with 4th Indian Division during Operation Compass; some Indian Army support units may have been attached

major_operations: Siege and capture of Bardia (3-5 Jan 1941)
Siege and capture of Tobruk (21-22 Jan 1941)
Preparation for Battle of Beda Fomm (early Feb)
historical_context.strategic_situation: Pursuing Italian 10th Army westward after victory at Sidi Barrani; rapidly advancing through Cyrenaica despite extended supply lines and mechanical attrition
historical_context.enemy_forces: Italian 10th Army (heavily demoralized and retreating); Corpo d'Armata di Manovra (mobile reserve)
historical_context.command_changes: Western Desert Force redesignated XIII Corps on 1 Jan 1941 under Lieutenant-General Richard O'Connor
historical_context.losses_to_date: Relatively light casualties but severe mechanical attrition - many tanks and vehicles non-operational due to wear
